sops.title: SOP 1: Master SOP for ALL Mensuration Problems
sops.goal: To never lose marks due to formula or calculation errors
steps: Identify the Shape(s): Name them immediately (e.g., cone + hemisphere)
Write the Formula FIRST: e.g., write CSA = πrl before substituting. (Secures method marks)
Final Check (Units & Accuracy): Correct units (e.g., cm², cm³) and required s.f./d.p.

pitfalls.text: Substituting numbers before writing the exact formula

pro_tips: Always write the formula first to lock in method marks
Box the final answer with units and accuracy

sops.title: SOP 2: Similar Figures & Solids
sops.goal: Correctly use scaling laws for length, area, and volume
steps: Find the Length Ratio (k) FIRST: k = Length₁ ÷ Length₂
Identify the Target: Area or Volume/Capacity/Mass?
Apply Power Rule: Area ratio = k². Volume/Capacity/Mass ratio = k³
Set up Proportion & Solve: Plug numbers into the correct ratio equation

pitfalls.text: Using k for area/volume without squaring/cubing

pro_tips: Always write k first, then immediately write k² or k³ before numbers
Draw a mini table with three rows: Length / Area / Volume = k / k² / k³

sops.title: SOP 3: Composite Solids
sops.goal: Find Total Surface Area (TSA) or Total Volume of combined shapes
steps: Deconstruct the Shape: List the basic parts clearly

Calculate Each Part Separately: Volume: sum volumes of parts. TSA (TRAP): only exposed surfaces count. Cone curved surface area: πrl. Hemisphere curved surface area: 2πr². Do NOT add base areas that are glued/hidden
Sum the Exposed Parts for TSA; sum volumes for total volume

pitfalls.text: Mixing up CSA vs TSA formulas or incorrectly adding base areas

pro_tips: Make a checklist of faces; mark 'hidden' vs 'exposed'
Calculate and label each part with units before summing

sops.title: SOP 4: Sector & Segment Problems
sops.goal: Accurately calculate properties of circle parts
steps: Check Angle Unit: Degrees vs radians determines formulas
Sector First: Arc length: (θ÷360)×2πr (degrees) or rθ (radians). Sector area: (θ÷360)×πr² (degrees) or ½r²θ (radians)
Segment: Master idea: Area of Segment = Area of Sector − Area of Triangle. Triangle area (using included angle): ½ab sinC. Perform the subtraction

pitfalls.text: Using degree formulas on radian inputs (or vice-versa)
Forgetting to subtract the triangle for a segment

pro_tips: Circle the angle unit at the start
Always write 'Segment = Sector − Triangle' before substituting numbers
